summary:
As a self-taught full-stack developer, I have almost 6 years of professional experience in software engineering, and a passion for IT and technology. My areas of expertise include React-Native, React, TypeScript, NodeJS, Flutter, SQL, Terraform, and AWS, with my main focus being React-Native. In addition to my technical skills, I'm interested in product and UI design, social and environmental issues such as global warming, healthy living, public transport/micromobility, city design, and active citizenship.

One of my notable accomplishments is creating an app called "Budipest," which maps public restrooms in Budapest. The app was presented in Shark Tank's Hungarian edition, and I collaborated with the City of Budapest to bring it to fruition. As a result, it quickly became the most downloaded app in Hungary, serving thousands of users and addressing a real societal issue.

I have also developed tutorial series, including one on learning Dart and Flutter for JS developers, and another on introductory React-Native. Additionally, I have experience speaking at meetups about mental health and the connection between philosophy and tech.

projects:
[{'title': 'RIDDIMFUTÁR', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': "Imagine the following: when getting on a public transport vehicle, you open up an app and real-time riddim music starts banging from your phone. As you get closer to the next stop, the music gets more and more intense until you reach the stop and a sick beat drops along with the stop name announcement. This is exactly RIDDIMFUTÁR - the app generates real-time, gapless riddim/electro music for your public transport journeys in Budapest. The app is tied up with BKK's FUTÁR API for real-time traffic and public transport information, generates gapless music real-time as you move towards your destination, plays the already familiar stop signals and more.

In short: it's state of the art technology for a state of the art meme app.

This is my most complex project so far. It consists of three parts:
- the mobile app (Flutter): https://github.com/dnlgrgly/riddimfutar-ui
- the backend (NodeJS, BKK FUTÁR API, GCP, MongoDB): https://github.com/dnlgrgly/riddimfutar-api
- the CLI utilities (NodeJS, BKK FUTÁR API, Google Cloud speech API): https://github.com/dnlgrgly/riddimfutar-utils
- Google Play and App Store URLs dropping soon!
- I'll also make a demo YouTube video for those who want to feel the vibe of the app but don't live in Budapest. Stay tuned!", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dániel', 'last_name': 'Gergely', 'name': None, 'headline': 'React-Native Developer'}]}, {'title': 'Budipest', 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'Are you downtown, and in urgent need of a toilet? Budipest helps!

Budipest is a community-based toilet finder app that seeks to alleviate the problem of public toilets in Hungary by making existing toilets more visible, and displaying restrooms in clubs and bars that are open to anyone.

The main features of Budipest:
- See restrooms around you on a map and in a list
- Check the opening hours of restrooms, and their main features (eg. free or paid, price of entry, accessibility, etc.)
- Rate toilets or add helpful comments to them
- Anyone can add new toilets to the app

The app was built with Flutter and it has a backend made with NodeJS/Express hosted on Heroku, and a mongoDB database.

Mobile repository: https://github.com/dnlgrgly/budipest-mobile
Backend repository: https://github.com/dnlgrgly/budipest-api
App Store and Google Play URLs coming very soon!', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dániel', 'last_name': 'Gergely', 'name': None, 'headline': 'React-Native Developer'}]}, {'title': 'Nagyiposta (backend)', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': "Nagyiposta is an easy to use postcard service. You can upload an image and get it posted to your grandma (or others) for a fixed price.

On this project, our goal as a small team at RisingStack was to re-write the frontend in React and to create a new backend API. I contributed a small part to the frontend and I made the whole backend API with Serverless framework and AWS Lambda functions.

The API handles Stripe payments, uploading the image to S3 (with a signed URL), and creating a new Trello card on the client's side for every postcard.", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dániel', 'last_name': 'Gergely', 'name': None, 'headline': 'React-Native Developer'}]}, {'title': 'shapeblinder', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': 'This is the demo project for my publication "Dart and Flutter crash course for JS developers"

In this game, there's a shape hidden on the screen and you need to find it. If you tap inside the shape, you'll feel some haptic feedback or vibration, and with the help of this feedback (and some imagination), you'll be able to find the hidden shape.

App Store: https://apps.apple.com/hu/app/shapeblinder/id1523640121
Google Play: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=hu.danielgrgly.shapeblinder
GitHub: https://github.com/risingstack/shapeblinder', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dániel', 'last_name': 'Gergely', 'name': None, 'headline': 'React-Native Developer'}]}, {'title': 'Jegyesnaptár (design, frontend)', 'date': {'start': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': 'Jegyesnaptár aims to ease the task of organising a wedding the easiest thing in the world. You can add all your wedding-related vendors (e.g. makeup masters, props, flowers, cameraman, etc.) and find out when all of them are going to be available. You can also book them right via the app - no need to call each one of them. They can accept and decline your wedding invitation.

I made some parts of the frontend with React and Bootstrap, and I designed the whole project with Adobe XD. We worked on this project in a three-person team at RisingStack. The main purpose of the project was to help people reorganise their weddings until after the COVID-19 crisis.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dániel', 'last_name': 'Gergely', 'name': None, 'headline': 'React-Native Developer'}]}, {'title': 'Pokédex', 'date': {'start': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': 'An example app for the react-easy-state library, hooked up with a GraphQL API, and deployed to Vercel.

Live deployment: https://pokedex-six.now.sh
GitHub URL: https://github.com/dnlgrgly/pokedex', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dániel', 'last_name': 'Gergely', 'name': None, 'headline': 'React-Native Developer'}]}, {'title': 'ColorBlinder', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}}, 'description': "A React-Native and Expo-based mobile app built for my RisingStack blog series “Getting to know React-Native as a React developer: a definitive guide”. It’s a fun and small game. The main goal: find the differing tile from a group of seemingly same squares as fast as possible. It's the third re-iteration of this concept: I built this game in Unity and vanilla React-Native before building with Expo.", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dániel', 'last_name': 'Gergely', 'name': None, 'headline': 'React-Native Developer'}]}]
